content: A rare degenerative mitochondrial disease characterized by chronic metabolic acidosis, hypotonia, facial dysmorphism and delayed development.
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)

content: Congenital lactic acidosis, saguenay-lac-saint-jean type is considered a genetics disease.
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)

content: Congenital lactic acidosis, saguenay-lac-saint-jean type is considered a neurology disease.
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)

content: Congenital lactic acidosis, saguenay-lac-saint-jean type is considered a metabolic disease.
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)

content: Congenital lactic acidosis, saguenay-lac-saint-jean type is considered a mitochondrial disease.
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)

content:
The age symptoms may begin to appear differs between diseases. Symptoms may begin in a single age range, or during several age ranges. Knowing when symptoms may have appeared can help medical providers find the correct diagnosis.

For this condition, symptoms may start to appear during: Infancy and Neonatal.
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)

content: Congenital lactic acidosis, saguenay-lac-saint-jean type may be caused by genetic mutations.
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)

content: Congenital lactic acidosis, saguenay-lac-saint-jean type may be caused by disruption in metabolism.
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)

content: Congenital lactic acidosis, saguenay-lac-saint-jean type may be caused by impaired mitochondrial function.
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)

content: Congenital lactic acidosis, saguenay-lac-saint-jean type is caused by genetic mutations in the following known gene(s): LRPPRC. Learn more about these genes by searching them on the National Library of Medicine (NLM)[https://medlineplus.gov/genetics/gene/]. Given these known genetic mutation(s), you may want to ask your health care team if genetic testing is right for you. Genetic tests are laboratory tests that use samples of blood, saliva, or other tissues to help identify changes in genes, chromosomes, or proteins. Genetic testing can help confirm or rule out a suspected genetic disease or can provide other useful information to your health care team. Learn more about genetic testing from the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI)[https://www.genome.gov/FAQ/Genetic-Testing].
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)

content: Yes. It is possible for a biological parent to pass down genetic mutations that cause or increase the chances of getting Congenital lactic acidosis, saguenay-lac-saint-jean type to their child. This is known as inheritance. Knowing whether other family members have previously had this disease, also known as family health history, can be very important information for your medical team.
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)

content: Congenital lactic acidosis, saguenay-lac-saint-jean type can be inherited in a Autosomal recessive pattern.
synonyms: cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, French-Canadian type
mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 5, (French-Canadian)
